results.title: The X-files = The X files
results.brief_description: Chris Carter’s long running cult series which explores the paranormal and the paranoid, introduced us to the covert world of FBI agents Dana Scully (Gillian Anderson) and Fox Mulder (David Duchovney) and its now famous mantra, “The truth is out there.”

results.title: The Wynns, winegrowers
results.brief_description: Traces the growth of the Wynn’s family wind business over 50 years. From small beginnings they now own large vineyards in various parts of Australia. Illustrates the organisation of the entire industry from growing the grapes to marketing bottled table wines, champagne and flagons.
results.description: Traces the growth of the Wynn’s family wind business over 50 years. From small beginnings they now own large vineyards in various parts of Australia. Illustrates the organisation of the entire industry from growing the grapes to marketing bottled table wines, champagne and flagons.

results.title: The Wyeth phenomenon
results.brief_description: In this film, critics and admirers discuss Mr. Wyeth’s style and subjects and try their hand at uncovering meanings in his art. Discussing the artist are the art critic of “The New York Times”, John Canady; artist Henriette Hurd (Wyeth’s sister); and Wyeth’s son, James.

results.title: The Wrong Man
results.creator_credit: Herbert Coleman, Warner Bros Pictures and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: A tense thriller based on the true story of an honest man mistaken for an armed robber. When Christopher Balestrero (Henry Fonda) decides to borrow money on his wife’s insurance policy to pay urgent debts, a tragic chain of events is set off because the staff of the insurance company believe him to be a man who previously held up their office.

results.title: The Writing on the screen
results.creator_credit: Carol Stowe, Mark Anderson, Lois Bianchi, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Shape of the world”.
Modern mapping technologies enable us to compile information on everything from earthquakes, AIDS epidemics and mineral exploration to the structure of the human brain. The mapping of our planet’s physical features is now complete, but its future well-being is largely in our hands. Using remote sensing technologies we can map changes in the natural world, and chart the warning signals - but will we use this knowledge to prevent disaster before it is too late?

results.title: The Writer in exile: James Joyce
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th century novel”.
Graham Martin examines the theme of the writer in exile during the early part of the twentieth century, and takes as an example the Irish writer James Joyce. Denys Hawthorne, as James Joyce, reads from Joyce’s letters, poems and novels

results.title: The Worship of nature; The Fallacies of hope; Heroic materialism
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Michael Gill and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode numbers 11, 12 and 13 of Series “Civilisation”.
Part 11. Christianity was the chief creative force in Western civilisation until about 1730, when it became eclipsed by the worship of nature. Part 12. The French Revolution led, not to freedom, but to terror, the dictatorship of Napoleon and the bureaucracies of the 19th century. Part 13. The final program shows how the heroic materialism of the past hundred years has been linked with an equally remarkable increase in humanitarianism.

results.title: The Worlds of Rudyard Kipling
results.brief_description: The film uses over 600 still photographs to present Kipling- the poet, novelist, patriot and chauvinist- and his love of America, India and South Africa. Narrated by Anthony Quayle.
